_data.description: My experience installing MacOS Catalina on my Lenovo V330
_data.title: My Laptop With OpenCore

While its screen is lacking in quite a few features its upgradability was superb and it already had

- this however has recently died off and hasn't been updated to work with MacOS Catalina, so I started doing my own research into OpenCore to create a "working" install this was made easier by the use of the

_data.text:
## Introduction

In 2018 I was looking for a laptop to complete coursework on, it needed to be powerful enough to do work on fairly complex Java and Node projects but at a low price tag - I found the Lenovo V330 to be a perfect match. While its screen is lacking in quite a few features its upgradability was superb and it already had [a guide to Hackintosh it](https://www.tonymacx86.com/threads/guide-lenovo-v330-15ikb-using-clover-uefi-hotpatch.265841) - this however has recently died off and hasn't been updated to work with MacOS Catalina, so I started doing my own research into OpenCore to create a "working" install this was made easier by the use of the [step by step guides](https://dortania.github.io/OpenCore-Install-Guide/) made by the OpenCore community.

_data.title: Cube License

children.value: Cube License is a licensing system built to control the distribution of SpigotMC premium plugins by limiting the amount of machines or servers that the plugin can be used on at once, this is accomplished by having a fixed machine lifetime for licenses which are then renewed automatically. Specifics of how this system works cannot be discussed in detail here.

Analytics were included to help plugin developers understand their main focus areas such as the version of the Spigot API which they should be building against and how often user's update their plugin.

props.alt: Analytics dashboard for a resource with graphs for checks, plugin version, operating system distribution, and server version

children.value: Overrides and bans were implemented to either set a specific machine count for a user or block a user from using the resource, this is useful in the case of them leaking or attempting to crack the resource.

props.alt: User overrides page with table of overridden users and form to create overrides

_data.text:
## Introduction
Cube License is a licensing system built to control the distribution of SpigotMC premium plugins by limiting the amount of machines or servers that the plugin can be used on at once, this is accomplished by having a fixed machine lifetime for licenses which are then renewed automatically. Specifics of how this system works cannot be discussed in detail here.
## Features
- User Overrides - User Bans - Analytics - Team Based Resources - Database Filtering - Two-Factor Authentication - Session Management
## Analytics
Analytics were included to help plugin developers understand their main focus areas such as the version of the Spigot API which they should be building against and how often user's update their plugin.
## User Overrides and Bans
Overrides and bans were implemented to either set a specific machine count for a user or block a user from using the resource, this is useful in the case of them leaking or attempting to crack the resource.

Initially emote.land was written in only 2 hours with basic copy-paste functionality completed.

will trigger a build and upload it to the gh-pages repository, when building each of the images are resized appropriately (48x48), this allows me to host the website without having to worry about bandwidth or server uptime.

_data.text:
## Introduction
Emote Land (yes it hosts emoji's, but emoji.land was £1000) was created when there were emotes that I wanted to use but couldn't justify the cost of Discord Nitro, it's a neat compromise for those who don't spam pepegas or kekws. Initially emote.land was written in only 2 hours with basic copy-paste functionality completed.
## Features
* Responsive * Automatic resizing of images * Quick Copy & Paste * Local Favourites! * 70+ Themes
## How it works
Emote Land is created with [Nuxt](https://nuxtjs.org) which supports the generation of static sites, whenever the repository is updated [Travis CI](https://travis-ci.com) will trigger a build and upload it to the gh-pages repository, when building each of the images are resized appropriately (48x48), this allows me to host the website without having to worry about bandwidth or server uptime.
## Credits
* Themes from [Monkey Type](https://monkeytype.com/) * All of the Emoji Artists

_data.title: Origin Realms

toc.text: Why wasn't it the final version?

children.value: This wasn't the final website used by Origin Realms and was completed during the early stages of development.
Eraze approached me to create a website based upon designs that he had made which were

themed, this was the basis of the website. The main page of the website needed to have a parallax effect which involved multiple layers of images moving at different factors according to how far the user had scrolled.

Another requirement was to have a trailer; however, the default YouTube embed was ugly (especially with it being one of the first elements the user will see), therefore I created a wrapper Vue element which would show a thumbnail with a stylised play button that would seamlessly transition into the YouTube embed.

To achieve the parallax I created a scroll function which would passively listen to the user scrolling, this would then calculate the amount of offset which each element needed according to their config, these offsets could be clamped to prevent further scrolling if required.
Why wasn't it the final version?

As previously stated, this was created during very early development, there simply wasn't enough room for content! The design ended up being completely overhauled and I sadly wasn't chosen to complete the second version; but, I'm still extremely grateful to have had the opportunity to work on such a unique project.

_data.text:
This wasn't the final website used by Origin Realms and was completed during the early stages of development.
## Introduction
Eraze approached me to create a website based upon designs that he had made which were [Minecraft](https://minecraft.net) themed, this was the basis of the website. The main page of the website needed to have a parallax effect which involved multiple layers of images moving at different factors according to how far the user had scrolled. Another requirement was to have a trailer; however, the default YouTube embed was ugly (especially with it being one of the first elements the user will see), therefore I created a wrapper Vue element which would show a thumbnail with a stylised play button that would seamlessly transition into the YouTube embed.
## Achieving the Parallax
To achieve the parallax I created a scroll function which would passively listen to the user scrolling, this would then calculate the amount of offset which each element needed according to their config, these offsets could be clamped to prevent further scrolling if required. Example Element Config: ```js foreground: { style: "", speedFactor: 0.2, inverse: true, start: 345, end: 300 } ```
### Why wasn't it the final version?
As previously stated, this was created during very early development, there simply wasn't enough room for content! The design ended up being completely overhauled and I sadly wasn't chosen to complete the second version; but, I'm still extremely grateful to have had the opportunity to work on such a unique project.

_data.title: PixelShop

children.value: PixelShop is the continuation of PixelBot-Designer which is used to make art for

Pixel Bot, its designed to be more efficient and comply with states so that there aren't weird watch and event workarounds. Its components are based upon a window which allows for the workspace to be configured to the users liking.
Drawing of images upon a 24x24 grid
Exporting to compressed formats supported by the bot
Creation of animated art with an interactive timeline

_data.text:
*Cover Artwork by asrielo* ## Introduction
PixelShop is the continuation of PixelBot-Designer which is used to make art for [Laboratory424's](https://www.twitch.tv/laboratory424) Pixel Bot, its designed to be more efficient and comply with states so that there aren't weird watch and event workarounds. Its components are based upon a window which allows for the workspace to be configured to the users liking.
## Features
* Drawing of images upon a 24x24 grid * Exporting to compressed formats supported by the bot * Creation of animated art with an interactive timeline * User configurable workspace

_data.text:
The Demo uses the V2 branch, this may have issues. Status Page is planned for a rewrite to support the new Nuxt Content and cleanup code.
## Introduction
Status Page is a serverless alternative to allow for custom designed status pages at a cheap price by utilising the APIs from services such as [UptimeRobot](https://uptimerobot.com/) and hosting through [Github Pages](https://pages.github.com/). Its design is based upon [Atlassian's Status Page](https://www.atlassian.com/software/statuspage).
## Features
* Polling of external APIs through providers * Incident reporting * Light and Dark mode
## Configuration

### Theme Options ```js timezone: "Europe/London", // The timezone which all times should be converted to from UTC pageLimit: 10, // The amount of incidents or monitors which should be displayed on a single page title: { prefixed: "{prefix} | Status Page", // The title in the browser window default: "Status Page" // If a prefixed title isn't possible }, incidents: { overallDateFormat: "MMM D, YYYY", // The time format for a quick view of the incident updateDateFormat: "MMM D, hh:mm zz",// The time format for incident updates fullPageDateFormat: "MMM D, YYYY, hh:mm zz" // The time format for a full page incident }, header: { logo: "", // Should be a path to an image, if none is specified then it will use the name below name: "Status Page", // Name of the page link: "/", // Where clicking on the header banner should lead to, use false for nothing. internalLink: true, // If the link is internal or not showOverallStatus: false, // Whether an overall uptime for all monitors should be calculated and displayed. } ```
### Provider Options A provider is not required, its purpose is to automatically gather information from another websites API. ```js provider: { enabled: true, // If the provider should be used name: 'uptimerobot', // The name of the provider to use apikey: '{READ_ONLY_KEY}' // The access key for the API of the provider // More options may be required here depending upon the provider. } ```
### Monitors #### Specifying a Single Monitor ```js monitors: [ [ { name: "CDN", // The name of the monitor description: "We serve our content via a CDN, this makes it load as fast as possible.", // An optional description of the monitor provider_id: 782849159 // An ID which is required by the UptimeRobot Provider } ] ] ```
#### Specifying a Monitor Group ```js monitors: [ { group_name: "Services", // Name of the group description: "These services are core to our business.", // Optional description of the group collapsible: true, // If the group should be collapsible collapsed: false, // If the group should start collapsed monitors: [ // Monitors which belong to the group { name: "Demos", provider_id: 779382341 }, { name: "Images", description: "We host all of our images in a central location.", provider_id: 779428955 } ] } ] ```


## Developers

### Building Providers Providers consist of two main functions: ```js async init({ axios, config }) { // This function takes the axios instance and the config for the panel. // It's designed to setup some initial variables which can help reduce load on calls to fetchMonitor. } async fetchMonitor({ monitor }) { // This function receives the config of the specified monitor from the config, its response is detailed below. } ```
The `fetchMonitor` function should return a response such as: ```json { numOfDays: 7, // The amount of days to return with (from the current day) uptimeRatios: [ // The uptime of each individual day 100.00, 100.00, 100.00, 100.00 88.35, 100.00, 75.35 ], averageUptimes: { // The average uptime for certain timespans 90: 100.0, 60: 100.0, 30: 100.0 } latency: { // Latency of the monitor timestamps: ["20:53","21:03","21:18","21:43","21:58"], latency: [16,0,16,0,11] } } ```

_data.text:
## Introduction **StrikePractice-Web** is a website that integrates with [StrikePractice](https://www.spigotmc.org/resources/strikepractice-–-1v1-2v2-pvp-bots-tournaments-parties-kit-editor-gui-best-of-rounds-and-more.46906/) it allows for public display of players statistics and previous fights.
## Requirements * A Web Server running Apache 2 or NGINX * StrikePractice * A database which **both** StrikePractice and the Web Server can access.
## FAQ
Yes, there are language files in each theme (it is down to the author of the theme to support phrases).
Yes! Once I have time I'm planning on creating more included themes and some premium themes.
Yes! StrikePractice-Web uses the [Smarty](https://www.smarty.net/docs/en/) templating engine, this allows for full theming with adequate HTML and CSS Skills.
Contact me on Discord `LegendEffects#7781`, it costs £15 (GBP), transactions are handled through PayPal.
There is a no sale policy on this product, everyone has to pay the same price.
You can contact me on Discord to make an enquiry about this, I'm usually quite busy so may not have time.

## Troubleshooting
This is caused from the server not having permission to write to Altona/Storage, to fix this I recommend running. I have been unable to find an alternative permission to this. ```bash $ chmod -R 777 Altona/Storage ```
#### There are multiple reasons this can occur:
##### The Overall Stats Table Doesn't Load This is likely a web server configuration error, if you're running NGINX then you need to use the included `nginx.site.config`. If you're running Apache then ensure that the `.htaccess` file was uploaded and that `mod_rewrite` is enabled with: ```bash $ sudo a2enmod rewrite ```
If this doesn't work then you need to set `AllowOverride` to `All` in your Apache configuration, this can usually be found at `/etc/apache2/apache2.conf`. Example Config: ``` Options Indexes FollowSymLinks AllowOverride All Require all granted ``` Then restart your Apache Web Server ```bash $ sudo service apache2 restart ```
##### The Overall Stats Table Loads This is caused due to a ladder misconfiguration, go to your `Configuration/StrikePractice.php` configuration file and set the ladders to match the columns in the database `(DO NOT INCLUDE THE ELO_)`. Example Config: ```php "ladders" => array( "builduhc" => "BuildUHC", "combo" => "Combo", "debuff" => "Debuff", "nodebuff" => "NoDebuff" ), ```
This likely means that you're running a cracked server, I will never add support for translation within StrikePractice-Web as I disagree with the practice; however, you can use another head rendering service such as [Minotar](https://minotar.net/) which supports usernames.
